title: Screening distances
content:
Guidelines for evaluating the noise impact of a maintenance facility near a school may specify certain screening distances to select schools, but they are ‘NOT a substitute for case- and site-specific evaluation of potential risks and hazards’. These distances may not be a good predictor of an environmental hazard.
 Federal Transportation Administration (FTA) guidelines mention
 that ‘a maintenance facility near a school’ (p. 33) is one location recommended for a ‘Detailed Noise Analysis’  The ‘screening distance for noise assessments’ at a school is  1,000 feet for unobstructed distances 650 feet for obstructed distances (‘with intervening buildings’)    According to the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) school siting guidelines
 If Creekside Elementary were to be built in 2020 at its current location and the school district was evaluating its current location as a new school location, recommendations include  identification and evaluation of any rail yards (‘excluding electric light rail, except for safety’) within a 1-mile radius for new schools (p19, EPA school siting guidelines).  School siting guidelines do not specify radius for electric light rail, but many of the same potential hazards apply here: noise, ground water contamination, accidental releases/spills of hazardous chemicals, large truck traffic.  Have there been other light rail systems that have assessed elementary schools more than 1,000 feet away with intervening buildings when doing noise assessments for a railyard operations maintenance facility (ROMF)?
 Sound Transit in Seattle, WA conducted a 2016 noise study at an elementary school, one mile away from the Sounder Yard and Shops Facility Project.

This web site is a curated collection of publicly available and relevant information about the approved Railyard Operations Maintenance Facility (ROMF) site as it relates to Creekside Elementary. As of February 2019, the entire school population has yet to receive information on the light rail railyard operations maintenance facility (ROMF), planned to be less than 0.25 miles away from the school.
The end does not justify the means.

title: About
content: This web site is a compilation of publicly available information on the planned location, construction, railyard features, timeline, and PTA activity. An action page wraps up this collection of information.

title: Location
content:
This railyard maintenance facility is planned for an industrial site at the intersection of Ephesus Church and Farrington Roads, less than 0.25 miles away from Creekside Elementary.
 On December 3, 2018, the Durham City Council approved an industrial rezoning for this location. The nearest industrial zone in Durham is over 4 miles away in Research Triangle Park.

title: Noise
content:
GoTriangle documents sources of noise from the railyard operations maintenance facility (ROMF) in their October 2018 ‘noise and vibration technical report’.
 The 2018 report mentions the following ROMF noise sources:
 Wheel squeal  ‘tight radius curves within the proposed ROMF have the potential to cause wheel squeal’  ‘SEL at 50 feet for LRT wheel squeal is assumed to be 136 dBA‘   Power substation  ‘proposed substation within the ROMF is assumed to operate continuously’  ‘SEL at 50 feet of 99 dBA’   Tree removal  ‘removal of up to 600 feet of intervening trees from the proposed ROMF site between Interstate 40 and sensitive receptors west of Farrington Road’  ‘assumed to increase existing highway noise from Interstate 40 by 10 dB’   Train movements  ‘The schedule of LRT train movements within the ROMF is assumed to be as follows’:  Daytime movements (7:00 AM to 10:00 PM): 32 total movements Nighttime movements (10:00 PM to 7:00 AM): 48 total movements    The 2015 noise report assumes the ROMF will operate at ‘SEL at 50 feet’ of 111 dBA (Table 3, page 19).
 This 111 dBA of noise estimate is paired with a note that ‘Resilient/damped wheels are incorporated into project design to reduce wheel squeal noise 10-20 decibels.’ ‘Wheel squeal’ estimated at 136 dBA, consistent with the 2018 report.

title: PTA February 2018 statement
content:
Statement on Rail Operations Maintenance Facility The Creekside PTA expresses its concern about the potential negative impacts of a Rail Operations Maintenance Facility (ROMF) in such close proximity to a school, as well as the lack of substantive communication with the school community during the planning process.
The Creekside PTA calls upon local leaders to immediately identify representatives to join a formal body that will work together to resolve concerns around potential impacts on student safety and quality of the learning environment. This body would meet regularly and openly and include representation from Durham Public Schools, Creekside PTA, Creekside Administration, Go Triangle, and government officials.
You can read the full statement here.

title: Chemical Storage
content:
’…regulated materials would be generated from maintenance activities at the ROMF.’ Source: Federal Environmental Impact Statement (FEIS)
 Upon a request from a homeowner in November 2018, GoTriangle provided a list of 144 chemicals that may be stored and transported to and from the railyard maintenance and operations facility.  Volumes range from household size to 1,000 gallon oil tanks. Many of these chemicals are hazardous, inflammable, and/or potentially explosive petroleum products. (Source: GoTriangle. ‘ROMF Fluids & Miscellaneous Materials Table.’ November 12, 2018). Thus far, there are no specific emergency response plans or evacuation area estimates in the event of an explosion, spill or ground contamination.    The Federal Environmental Impact Statement (FEIS) noted that there will be materials that could contaminate the groundwater at the ROMF.
 ‘While the light rail vehicles, as noted in section 4.8.3.1, do not operate on gasoline or oils that could spill and contaminate the groundwater through the operation of the light rail, as noted above, regulated materials would be generated from maintenance activities at the ROMF. As such, all regulated materials, including fluids (e.g., oils, greases, solvents and other waste materials), used at the ROMF will be captured and stored in tanks (inside buildings), where they will be periodically collected by an outside vendor for off-site recycling or disposal. All regulated materials will be disposed of in accordance with state and local guidelines and no substantial indirect impacts are anticipated.’ The potential to contaminate groundwater – a ‘spill event’ – at this site is unclear.

title: Noise mitigation
content:
The GoTriangle 2018 noise report describes ways to mitigate (reduce) the noise:
 ROMF buildings: 5 dB berms: 10 dBA train wheel treatments: 2 dBA train design changes: 5 dBA  The GoTriangle 2015 noise report describes another way to mitigate wheel squeal, absent from the 2018 report.
 ‘Resilient/damped wheels are incorporated into project design to reduce wheel squeal noise 10-20 decibels.’   No written updates have followed the October 2018 noise report as of February 2018.

title: PTA information sheet
content:
General information about the ROMF facility distributed at the Feburary 2018 meeting  All light rail trains will be stored, tested, and maintained at this location. This is not a light rail station, it is an industrial railyard maintenance facility. The ROMF will operate 24⁄7. Creekside Elementary is approximately 350 yards from the proposed site. According to a mapping evaluation conducted by parents, Creekside Elementary will be closer to a ROMF than any other school in the country. The second closest is the Charlotte ROMF, where a middle school is 756.8 yards (2,270 ft), more than double the distance. The trees that separate Farrington Rd from I-40 will be cleared for the ROMF. (Source: GoTriangle. ‘Questions and Answers about the GoTriange Rail Operations and Maintenance Facility.’ November 1, 2018).  HISTORY OF KEY DECISIONS:
 July 2015: The Farrington Road site is selected for the ROMF. Four other sites were considered, including locations at Cornwallis Road, Leigh Village, Patterson Place, and the Duke Eye Center. (Source: GoTriangle. Ch. 8. ‘Evaluation of Alternatives,’ in ‘Durham-Orange Light Rail Transit Project: Combined Environmental Impact Statement.’ February 2016.) October 9, 2018: Durham Planning Commission did not vote in favor of rezoning the Farrington Rd site to light industrial (4 YES-4 NO). (Source and Report: City and County of Durham. ‘Consolidated Staff Report: ROMF.’ October 9, 2018. October 2018: Noise and Vibration Technical report is issued (see below). December 3, 2018: City Council voted to approve rezoning (see above).  NOISE RELATED INFORMATION:
 Vibration noise, train horns, warning signals, and break squeal noises will occur at the ROMF. The Noise and Vibration Technical Report states that the ‘tight radius curves within the proposed ROMF have the potential to cause wheel squeal as the radii of curvature are less than 100 times the width of the LRT trucks. The SEL at 50 feet for LRT wheel squeal is assumed to be 136 dBA and each train movement is assumed to generate five seconds of wheel squeal.’ (Source: GoTriangle. ‘Noise and Vibration Technical Report.’ October 2018., p. 29, 5.1.2) Creekside was not included in the noise testing sites because it lies outside the FTA recommended distance of 650 ft for ROMF, 350 ft for tracks. This means there is no data related how the noises from the ROMF will impact the Creekside community. (Source for recommended distances: FTA. ‘Transit Noise and Vibration Impact Assessment Manual.’ September 2018). GoTriangle has offered the following mitigation measures: to place a 4 ft berm between the ROMF and Farrington Rd, as well as plant 8 ft ornamental trees, spaced 16 ft apart. GoTriangle also cites the ROMF buildings themselves as noise buffers. GoTriangle indicated at the Planning Commission meeting that it was not possible to raise the buffer.  HAZARDOUS MATERIAL INFORMATION:
 According to a document shared from another ROMF (shared with neighbors by GoTriangle) the facility will store and transport 144 chemicals in volumes ranging from household size to 1,000-gallon oil tanks (maximum). Many of these chemicals are hazardous, inflammable, and/or potentially explosive petroleum products. (Source: GoTriangle. ‘ROMF Fluids & Miscellaneous Materials Table.’ November 12, 2018). There are no specific emergency response plans or evacuation area estimates in the event of an explosion, spill or ground contamination.  TRAFFIC INFORMATION:
 There is an at-grade (at street level) crossing planned for Farrington Rd. Traffic will be halted at at-grade crossings for 50 seconds for each train crossing; There will be approximately 150 crossings per day at each at-grade crossing. There is no plan to add additional traffic lanes on Farrington Rd (outside of turning lanes and bike lanes).  COMMUNICATION ABOUT THE ROMF:
 There have been several GoTriangle meetings at Creekside since August 2015 for members of the surrounding community, but there were no formal invitations to Creekside parents for these meetings. Parents sought a meeting with GoTriangle in advance of the December 3, 2018, public hearing and City Council vote; the meeting was held on December 1, 2018, at South Regional Library. Creekside administration has indicated that the ‘school is not taking a position on the proposed light rail and ROMF on Farrington Road.’ The administration noted that the ‘school is attending community meetings to gather information’ and that ‘if there is information that something will impact the school (positively or negatively), admin. will work with district officials to problem-solve as necessary.’ (Source: Creekside PTA-SIT. Principal’s Report.’ November 15, 2018).  You can see the full document here.

title: How will this affect the school?
content:
Based on written information on the railyard operations maintenance facility (ROMF) provided in 2018, no evidence supports the conclusion that noise will not be a problem for children at Creekside Elementary.
Absence of evidence does not mean evidence of absence.
Will there be noise at Creekside Elementary during the construction phase and during operation of the ROMF?
 Based on the two noise reports issued in 2015 and 2018, the ROMF offers the potential to repeatedly emit noise over 60 dB, the current Durham City ordinance limit, more than 30 times a day.
 At a meeting requested by Creekside parents in November 2018, GoTriangle confirmed that no noise testing had been done at Creekside Elementary.

title: Traffic
content:
Upon completion of the ROMF and light rail system:
 Trains approaching the railyard operations maintenance facility (ROMF) from Chapel Hill will cross Farrington road near Wendell Road around 150 times a day, with road closures of 50 seconds for each crossing.
 These temporary road closures to allow train crossings will cause cars to stop, creating back-ups for people approaching Creekside Elementary from Farrington Road and 54.  Over 100 employees will park at the ROMF industrial location, presumably on a daily basis.
 During the construction phase starting in 2020, Farrington Road overpass will have temporary closures.
 Farrington Road will never be widened from its current two-lane configuration.
